note_models.name: Basic

fields: Do you know where this Anki deck originated?

This deck is part of an open collaborative effort started by YYC Net Lab. This deck is provided free of charge and without warranty. For updates please see the link below. If you notice any errors or would like to add some cards please reach out to YYC Net Lab through Github.

To stop seeing this card click on 'More' in the bottom right and select 'Suspend Card'.
What is the acronym used for the Central Processing Unit?
What acronym is used for Random Access Memory?
What, at its most basic level, does a computer do?
Take an input, process it, and provide an output.
What is a device which takes an input, processes it, and provides an output?
For safety, electrical equipment must be what before beginning work?
What must be grounded before beginning work for safety reasons?
What might occur when power adapters with different specifications are swapped between devices?
What component can damage equipment when swapped between devices with different requirements?
What is the acronym used for Electrostatic Discharge?
What type of electricity is an electrostatic discharge?
What occurs when there is a buildup of static electricity?
While an ESD needs to be 3000 volts to be felt, how many volts are needed to damage a computer component?
A computer component can be damaged with a 30-volt electrostatic discharge. How many volts are needed for a person to feel the discharge?
To avoid electrostatic discharge, how should components be stored?
What is the purpose of antistatic bags?
How can a person discharge any static electricity before working on electronics?
Why touch a grounded object before working on electronics?
What is the name for the process of discharging static electricity before working on electronics?
The process of discharging static electricity before working on electronics
How can a workspace be grounded to prevent static buildup?
Use grounded floor mats, grounded workbench mats, and antistatic wrist straps.
What do grounded floor mats, grounded workbench mats, and antistatic wrist straps do?
Ground the workspace to prevent static buildup
Which part houses the delicate components of a computer?
What is the purpose of the case?
To house the components of a computer
What does the term 'form factor' refer to?
The physical shape and design of the device's exterior
What term refers to the physical shape and design of a device's exterior?
What are alternate terms for a computer case?
Chassis, cabinet, tower, housing, or box
What term is a synonym of the terms chassis, cabinet, tower, housing, or box?
What does the acronym HTPC stand for?
What is the acronym for Home Theatre PC?
Which form factor was most popular in early home computers?
In which computers were horizontal cases most popular?
Which form factor is commonly found in corporate environments?
Where are compact towers commonly found?
What are alternative terms for a compact tower?
Mini tower or small form factor (SFF)
What form factor do the alternate terms 'mini tower' and 'small form factor (SFF)' refer to?
Which component converts AC power to DC power?
What does a power supply (PSU) do?
Convert AC power to DC power
What is the acronym for Advanced Techology Extended?
Which power supply form factors are now considered obsolete?
What are the original AT and ATX power supply form factors now that newer form factors are more common?
What is the most common power supply form factor today?
What is the ATX12V power supply form factor in comparison to the other form factors available?
What was the EPS12V power supply form factor originally designed for?
What power supply form factor was originally designed for network servers?
Which power supply is common in high-end desktop PCs?
What is the acronym used for the Central Processing Unit?
What acronym is used for Random Access Memory?

Take an input, process it, and provide an output.

What must be grounded before beginning work for safety reasons?

Why touch a grounded object before working on electronics?

The process of discharging static electricity before working on electronics

Use grounded floor mats, grounded workbench mats, and antistatic wrist straps.

Ground the workspace to prevent static buildup

What is the purpose of the case?
To house the components of a computer

The physical shape and design of the device's exterior

Chassis, cabinet, tower, housing, or box

What does the acronym HTPC stand for?
What is the acronym for Home Theatre PC?
Which form factor was most popular in early home computers?
In which computers were horizontal cases most popular?
Which form factor is commonly found in corporate environments?
Where are compact towers commonly found?
What are alternative terms for a compact tower?
Mini tower or small form factor (SFF)
What form factor do the alternate terms 'mini tower' and 'small form factor (SFF)' refer to?
Which component converts AC power to DC power?
What does a power supply (PSU) do?
Convert AC power to DC power
What is the acronym for Advanced Techology Extended?
Which power supply form factors are now considered obsolete?
What are the original AT and ATX power supply form factors now that newer form factors are more common?
What is the most common power supply form factor today?
What is the ATX12V power supply form factor in comparison to the other form factors available?
What was the EPS12V power supply form factor originally designed for?
What power supply form factor was originally designed for network servers?
Which power supply is common in high-end desktop PCs?
What does the acronym 'PSU' stand for?
What acronym is used for the 'Power Supply' of a PC?
A connector designed to only be inserted one way
What is the term for a connector only designed to be inserted one way?
How many pins does the main power connector for the motherboard have?
20 or 24 - two rows of 10 or two rows of 12
Which component does the power supply's 20- or 24-pin connector plug into?
What does a SATA power connector power?
Hard drives, solid state drives, DVD drives, and other similar components.
What type of connector is used to power hard drives, solid state drives, and DVD drives?
A legacy standard capable of carrying more power than SATA, but in modern use is rarely used to power anything but small accessories such as lighting controllers.
Which legacy power connector standard used to power components like hard drives and video cards, but is now relegated mostly to accessories?
Legacy connector used to power floppy drives. It is smaller than a Molex connector.
Which legacy connector is smaller than a Molex connector and used to power floppy drives?
The 4- to 8-pin auxiliary power connector powers what?
The connector plugs into the motherboard and supplies power to individual components attached to the motherboard, such as the CPU.
What type of connector powers the CPU and other individual motherboard components?
Which connector is used to supply power to internal components other than the motherboard?
The 6- to 8-pin PCIe connector is used to supply power to what?
The connector powers internal components other than the motherboard, such as a video card
What are the most common voltages supplied by different PSU connectors?
3.3 volts, 5 volts, and 12 volts are what?
The most common PSU connector voltages
What type of component makes use of the PSU's 3.3 volt and 5 volt connectors?
What PSU connector voltages are typically consumed by digital circuits?
What type of component typically uses one of a PSU's 12-volt connectors?
Disk drive and fan motors use which voltage connector from a PSU?
What is the physical difference between a single and multiple-rail power supply?
A single-rail PSU has all of its connectors connected to the same PCB, while a multi-rail PSU has a separate PCB for each connector.
What type of PSU has all connectors on one PCB, and what type of PSU has a separate PCB for each connector?
A printed circuit board (PCB) to which external cables are connected
What is the name for the printed circuit board (PCB) inside a PSU to which external cables are connected?
What are the primary advantages and disadvantages of a multi-rail PSU vs a single-rail PSU?
A multi-rail PSU will have more stable power with fewer fluctuations, however it is capable of handling less amperage
What kind of PSU has the advantage of more stable power delivery but the disadvantage of being capable of supplying fewer amps?
Which power supply form factor does not support 3.3volt connectors?
The original AT power supply form factor
The original AT power supply form factor did not support which voltage connector?
What are alternate names for the motherboard?
What component do the terms 'system board' and 'main board' refer to?
What biological component of humans is analogous to the motherboard of a PC?
The 'backbone' of a computer is which component?
A large printed circuit board (PCB) that contains buses that interconnect electronic components
Which important component of a PC is essentially just a PCB that contains buses that interconnect electronic components?
How are components connected to the motherboard?
Components can be soldered directly to the PCB or added using sockets, expansion slots, and ports
Solder, sockets, expansion slots, and ports are used for what purpose?
Connecting electrical components to the motherboard
An electrical pathway that connects electronic components
What is the name for an electrical pathway that connects electronic components
What does the acronym 'RAM' stand for?
What is the acronym used for Random Access Memory?

A large printed circuit board (PCB) that contains buses that interconnect electronic components

Components can be soldered directly to the PCB or added using sockets, expansion slots, and ports
Solder, sockets, expansion slots, and ports are used for what purpose?
Connecting electrical components to the motherboard
An electrical pathway that connects electronic components
What is the name for an electrical pathway that connects electronic components
What does the acronym 'RAM' stand for?
What is the acronym used for Random Access Memory?
What are the expansion slots on a motherboard used for?
The slots are used to connect additional optional components to a motherboard
Where are additional optional components connected to a motherboard?
The chipset is the set of integrated circuits that control how connected components interact with the CPU and motherboard
Which component of a motherboard controls how other components interact with the CPU and motherboard?
In addition to its other functions, the chipset establishes limits to what?
The amount of RAM and types of connectors that the motherboard can support
What establishes limits to the amount of RAM and types of connectors a motherboard supports?
What acronym is used for the 'Basic Input/Output System'?
What acronym is used for the 'Unified Extensible Firmware Interface'?
Low-level programming that allows an operating system to interact with and control hardware
What is the name for the low-level programming that allows an operating system to interact with and control hardware?
A BIOS helps boot older computers and manages the flow of data between components
What helps boot older computers and manage the flow of data between components?
What specifies the firmware for boot and runtime services on newer computers?
What does the UEFI do for newer computers?
Specifies the firmware for boot and runtime services
What is the purpose of the CPU?
Information processing - it is the brain of the computer
What component is the 'brain' of the computer?
What is the purpose of RAM?
RAM is a high-speed, temporary storage location for data and applications.
What component acts as the 'short-term memory' of the computer, storing data on a temporary basis?
What are the two sub-components of most chipsets?
What are the northbridge and southbridge contained within?
What is the purpose of the northbridge?
The northbridge controls high-speed connections between the RAM, CPU, and sometimes PCIe video cards
What controls the high-speed connections between the RAM, CPU, and sometimes PCIe video cards?
What is the purpose of the southbridge?
The southbridge controls low-speed connections between the CPU and devices such as hard drives, USB ports and low-speed PCI slots
What controls low-speed connections between the CPU and devices such as hard drives, USB ports, and low-speed PCI slots?
What are the three common form factors of motherboard?
ATX, Micro-ATX, and Mini-ITX are what?
The 3 most common motherboard form factors
What acronym is used for the 'Information Technology Extended' form factor?
Which motherboard form factor is the single most common?
ATX is the single most ______ motherboard form factor
What are the similarities and differences between ATX and Micro-ATX?
MicroATX is smaller than ATX, but is designed to be compatible with all of the same connectors and components as ATX
Despite being smaller than ATX, this form factor is compatible with all of the same power connectors and components
What is the advantage of Mini-ITX vs ATX?
ITX is significantly smaller than ATX and is designed to run quieter and cooler; often with less power
This motherboard form factor is significantly smaller than ATX and designed to run quieter and cooler, sometimes with less power
What is the primary disadvantage of smaller motherboard form factors?
Smaller form factors such as ITX have fewer expansion slots and are sometimes unable to use components with high power consumption
Which form factors have the disadvantage of fewer expansion slots and sometimes incompatibility with components with high power consumption?
Smaller form factors such as Mini-ITX
What is the acronym used for 'Power-On Self Test'?
What is the CPU responsible for?
Interpreting and executing commands, handling instructions from input devices, and outputting information to output devices
What component is responsible for interpreting and executing commands, handling instructions from input devices, and outputting information to output devices?
Who are the two most popular desktop CPU manufacturerers?
The two most popular desktop CPU manufacturers
The connection between the motherboard and the CPU
What is the name for the connection between the motherboard and the CPU?
What acronym is used for 'Pin-grid array' architectures?
What acronym is used for 'Land Grid Array' architectures?
What is a pin-grid array architecture?
An architecture in which there are pins on the underside of the processor which are inserted into holes in the socket on the motherboard
In which architecture are pins on the underside of the CPU inserted into holes in the socket on the motherboard?
What is a land grid array architecture?
An architecture in which pins are located in the socket and make contact with electrical contact pads on the underside of the CPU
In which architecture are pins are located in the socket and make contact with electrical contact pads on the underside of the CPU?
Which CPU manufacturer usually uses PGA architecture?
LGA is usually used by which manufacturer?
What acronym is used for 'Zero Insertion Force'?
The amount of force required to install a CPU into its socket
What term is used to describe the amount of force required to install a CPU into its socket?
What are the two ways to cool an electronic component?
What do active and passive cooling refer to?
Methods of keeping electronic components cool
What can occur if too much heat builds up inside a computer?
Poor performance, system instability, crashes, and component damage
What results in poor performance, system instability, crashes, and component damage?
Too much heat buildup inside a computer
What is the most common active cooling method for computer components?
The most common method of active cooling
What is the most common method of passive cooling?
What are heat sinks in relation to fans?
The most common method of passive cooling
How many bits are in a byte?
What does a grouping of 8 bits make up?
What are the two possible values of a bit?
What unit has the two possible values of 0 and 1?
What is the acronym used for 'Read-Only Memory'?
What is the purpose of ROM?
ROM stores pre-set instructions for the CPU that allow it to perform basic operations like booting the computer and loading the operating system
What type of memory stores pre-set instructions for the CPU that allow it to perform basic operations like booting the computer and loading the operating system?
What does 'nonvolatile' mean in reference to computer memory?
Nonvolatile means that the memory is not erased when the computer is powered off
This type of memory is not erased when the computer is powered off
Memory that is erased when it loses power
What type of memory is erased when power is lost?
Installing more RAM can result in what?
Systems can gain improved performance by installing more of what component?
What are the three types of user-programmable ROM?
What are PROM, EPROM, and EEPROM?
The three types of user-programmable ROM
What is the type of ROM that only the manufacturer can program?
A type of ROM only programmable by the manufacturer
What is the acronym used for 'Programmable Read Only Memory'?
What acronym is used for Erasable Programmable Read Only Memory?
Electrically Erasable Programmable Read Only Memory
What acronym is used for Electrically Erasable Programmable Read Only Memory?
This type of user-programmable ROM can only be programmed once and cannot be erased.
PROM can be programmed how many times?
Strong ultraviolet light erases what kind of ROM?
Erasing and reprogramming this type of memory too many times can render it useless.
EPROM can be rendered useless by doing what?
Erasing and reprogramming too many times
Which type of ROM can be reprogrammed without removing it from the device?
EEPROM can be reprogrammed without what?
What is an important use for EEPROM chips on motherboards?
What type of memory is often used to store the BIOS/UEFI?
What is the acronym used for Dynamic RAM?
What type of RAM was used for main system memory until the mid-1990s?
What was a primary disadvantage of DRAM?
It constantly discharges and needs constant pulses of electricity to maintain the stored data
Which type of RAM constantly discharges and needs constant pulses of electricity to maintain the stored data?
What are the main advantages of SRAM over DRAM?
Faster speed and lower power consumption
Which type of RAM is faster than and uses less power than DRAM, while being a similar age?
What acronym is used for Static RAM?
What is a common use-case for SRAM?
What type of RAM is commonly used in high-speed caches?
What acronym is used for Synchronous Dynamic RAM?
What are the differences between SDRAM and plain DRAM?
SDRAM is a type of DRAM that operates in synchronization with the memory bus, is able to process overlapping instructions in parallel, and has higher transfer rates
Which type of RAM is a type of DRAM that operates in synchronization with the memory bus, is able to process overlapping instructions in parallel, and has higher transfer rates?
What are the differences between DDR SDRAM and SDRAM?
DDR SDRAM transfers twice as much data at a lower voltage as SDRAM by supporting two writes and two reads per CPU clock cycle
Which type of RAM transfers twice as much data as SDRAM at a lower voltage by supporting two writes and two reads per CPU clock cycle?
How does DDR2 SDRAM transfer data twice as fast as SDRAM?
DDR2 SDRAM runs at a much higher clock speed and reduces noise and crosstalk while operating at a lower voltage
Which type of RAM transfers data twice as fast as SDRAM by running at a higher clock speed and reducing noise and crosstalk while operating at a lower voltage?
How does DDR3 improve upon DDR2?
Doubling clock speeds, consuming less power, and generating less heat
Which type of RAM improved upon DDR2 SDRAM by doubling clock speeds, consuming less power, and generating less heat?
How does DDR4 improve upon DDR3?
Quadrupling maximum storage capacity, running at a higher clock speed, consuming less power, and is available as an ECC variant
Which type of RAM improved upon DDR3 by quadrupling maximum storage capacity, running at a higher clock speed, consuming less power, and is available as an ECC variant?
What does ECC stand for in relation to memory?
What acronym is used for 'Error Correcting Code'?
Detects and corrects multiple-bit errors during reads and writes caused by magnetic and electrical interference inside a computer case
What type of memory detects and corrects multiple-bit errors during reads and writes caused by magnetic and electrical interference inside a computer case
What purpose is GDDR SDRAM designed for?
What type of RAM is designed specifically for computer graphics?
What occurs when data is not stored correctly in a memory chip?
Incorrectly-stored data in a memory chip
What type of memory module was difficult to install and often came loose?
DIP RAM was difficult to install and often came loose
What does 'DIP' stand for in relation to memory?
What acronym is used for Dual Inline Package memory modules?
What does 'SIMM' stand for in relation to memory?
What acronym is used for Single Inline Memory Modules?
What does 'DIMM' stand for in relation to memory?
What acronym is used for Dual Inline Memory Modules?
What does 'SODIMM' stand for in relation to memory?
Small Outline Dual Inline Memory Module
What acronym is used for 'Small Outline Dual Inline Memory Modules'?
Circuit boards which hold several memory chips
What names are used for the circuit boards that hold multiple memory chips?
Under what circumstances are SODIMMs used instead of DIMMs?
In devices where space is at a premium, such as laptops and printers
What type of memory modules are used in devices where space is at a premium, such as laptops?
What pin configurations are available on SIMMs?
What kind of memory module is available in 30-pin and 72-pin configurations?
What pin configurations are available on DIMMs?
What type of memory module is available in 168, 184, 240, and 288-pin configurations?
What pin configurations are available on SODIMMs?
72-pin and 100-pin for 32-bit transfers; 144, 200, 204, and 260-pin for 64-bit transfers
What type of memory module has 74, 100, 144, 200, 204, and 260-pin configurations?
Single-sided memory modules contain RAM on only one side of the PCB whereas double-sided memory modules contain RAM where?
On both sides of the PCB
Double-sided memory modules contain RAM on both sides of the PCB whereas single-sided memory modules contain RAM where?
On only one side of the PCB
The speed of memory has a direct impact on what?
The amount of data a processor can process in a given period of time
The amount of data a CPU can process in a given period of time is directly affected by what?
Adapter cards add additional functionality to a computer with controllers for specific devices or by adding ports.
What type of component increases the functionality of a computer by adding controllers for specific devices or by adding additional ports?
What does a sound card do?
Add additional audio capability to a computer
What kind of adapter card adds additional audio capability to a computer?
What acronym is used for Network Interface Cards?
Adds network connection capability via either a network cable or radio frequencies (WiFi)
What kind of adapter card adds network connection capability via either a network cable or radio frequencies (WiFi)?
What does a video adapter / video card do?
A video adapter provides video and computer graphics capability
What kind of adapter card adds video and computer graphics capability?
What is the purpose of a capture card?
A capture card sends a video signal to a storage drive to be recorded
What type of adapter card sends a video signal to a storage drive to be recorded?
What is the purpose of a TV tuner card?
A TV tuner card provides the capability to watch and record live television on a PC by connecting an existing TV service to it
What type of adapter card provides the capability to watch and record live television on a PC?
What is the purpose of a USB controller card?
A USB controller card adds additional USB ports to a computer for connecting peripheral devices.
What kind of card adds additional USB ports to a computer for connecting peripheral devices?
What is the purpose of an eSATA card?
An eSATA card adds additional SATA ports to a computer via a PCIe slot
What kind of adapter card adds additional SATA ports to a computer via a PCIe slot?
What acronym is used for the 'Small Computer System Interface'?
What acronym is used for the 'Accelerated Graphics Port'?
What is the general purpose of a storage device?
To provide non-volatile storage of data that is not lost when power is lost
What type of device has the purpose of providing non-volatile storage that is retained even when power is lost?
What are the three main media types on which data is stored?
Magnetic, solid state flash, and optical
Magnetic, solid state flash, and optical are ______.
The three main media types on which data is stored
What acronym is used for Advanced Technology Attachment?
What are the two types of ATA?
What are Serial ATA and Parallel ATA types of?
What are the original two PATA standards?
What are the three types of SATA?
What are SATA 1, SATA 2. and SATA 3?
What does the 'IDE' PATA standard stand for?
What acronym is used for the Integrated Drive Electronics PATA standard?
What does the 'EIDE' PATA standard stand for?
What acronym is used for the Enhanced Integrated Drive Electronics PATA standard?
What speeds can the original two PATA standards reach?
8.3 megabytes per second with IDE and 16.6 megabytes per second with EIDE
The top speeds of the original two PATA standards
What is the top speed of the final PATA standard?
At what point in the history of PATA standards was PATA able to reach 133Mbps?
What are the respective top speeds of the three SATA standards in gigabits per second?
1.5Gbps, 3Gbps, and 6Gbps are the top speeds of what standards?
What are two common types of magnetic data storage?
Hard Disk Drives (HDDs) and tape drives
Hard Disk Drives (HDDs) and tape drives are what class of storage?

The faster the spindle can spin, the faster the hard drive can locate data on the platter

Floppy drives are what class of storage?

SSDs store data as electrical charges in semiconductor flash memory

SSDs are much faster than HDDs

No moving parts, no noise, more energy efficient, faster, and produce less heat

This form factor is intended to be a drop-in replacement for HDDs. They can be mounted in bays designed for HDDs.

What is the purpose of the M.2 form factor?
These drives make use of a special socket designed specifically for them which allows much greater data throughput than SATA.
Which SSD form factor makes use of a special socket designed specifically for it?

SSHDs are a compromise between HDDs and SSDs on speed and price by combining a large HDD with a small cache of SSD storage.

DVI-A can carry a high-quality analog signal, but no digital data.

DVI-D can carry a digital signal, but not an analog signal

DVI-I can carry both digital and analog signals, giving it more flexibility
